At that time, there was an arhat in the assembly who knew the beginning and end of the heavenly son's causes and conditions. Because of this, he recalled:
My own teacher has passed away for a long time, but I do not know in which path he is.
At that time, a donor held a vegetarian feast in the temple. There was a bhiká¹£u who drew new clean water and distributed it to the assembly of monks during the vegetarian feast.
The arhat received the water in a white copper bowl and was about to drink it. He touched it with the tip of his finger and found it extremely clear and cool. He then thought to himself:
My teacher was once the abbot of a temple, in charge of the affairs of the great assembly. He was stingy with the property of the assembly and greedy for material things.
He always wished to be reborn in this place in his next life.
If he had such sins, he would fall into the boiling copper hell. How could he enjoy this sweet spring?
Having had this thought, he then entered concentration to observe, and searched through the hells, the animal realm, and the ghost realm, but did not see him anywhere.
He further contemplated:
How could it be that the good roots he planted in the past have now matured and he has been reborn in a superior place?
He then observed the heavens one by one, and saw that his teacher had been reborn in the Heaven of the Four Kings.

At that time, the Venerable One went to his place, consoled him, and said, I have heard that in order to be reborn in this heaven, one must cultivate many good deeds and strictly uphold pure precepts.
Teacher, you have accumulated past offenses. How could you have come here?
At that time, the Heavenly Son said to the Venerable One:ğŸ”½The Venerable One said:
In the past, I served as the head of a temple, but due to ignorance and evil conduct, I never confessed.
When my life was about to end, I was sincere and earnest, and only the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha were my refuge.
By recollecting the grace of the Three Jewels, and relying on this wholesome root, I was reborn here.

When the Venerable heard this, his mind was purified, he rejoiced, and attained what he had never had before. He then exclaimed How wonderful! three times among the assembly of humans, gods, learners, and adepts, and fully recounted the above events.

The power of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha is difficult to fathom. It can extinguish the immeasurable extreme suffering of hell, and can cultivate the immeasurable wholesome roots of sentient beings. It can cut off afflictions and tear apart the web of doubts, and ultimately reach the other shore of enlightenment.
The wise should diligently cultivate, purify body, speech, and mind, and cultivate giving, morality, and concentration. This can repay the great kindness of the Buddha.

However, the natures and desires of sentient beings are each different. Gradually, they are made to cultivate these three kinds of practices. Some enjoy the enjoyment of the five desires in the future. The World-Honored One skillfully encourages them to give in charity;
Some enjoy being born in the heavens and receiving wonderful and marvelous bliss. The World-Honored One skillfully makes them uphold pure precepts;
Some enjoy liberation and leaving behind the suffering of the limits. The World-Honored One skillfully makes them practice meditation.
Therefore, the World-Honored One speaks of these three practices as being called the cover of blessings. One should fully practice them.
It is like two ghosts competing over three kinds of things, namely a box, shoes, and a mallet. The two argue with each other, raising their voices and shouting, saying:
In a certain place, there is a Brahmin who is very upright. He can decide this matter.
The two ghosts carry the things and immediately go to that place, joining their palms and saying:
Great Brahmin!
You should distribute these things equally for us.
The Brahmin said:
These are trivial things.
Why do you compete with each other, coming from afar to seek a decision?
The two ghosts said:
This is not a small matter, it is extremely difficult to obtain.
You see this chest, which can transform and produce whatever you desire.
If a person steps on these two shoes, they can ascend to heaven and receive various wonderful pleasures.
Moreover, this hammer can subdue all enemies and make them retreat and scatter.
At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a, having heard this, ordered the two ghosts to step aside:
I will think about it for a long time for you, dividing these three things so that each gets an equal share.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a then quickly put on the shoes, took the hammer and chest, and flew away through the air.
The two ghosts, having seen this, regretted letting him know about the three things and that they belonged to someone else.
In this parable, one should discern well that giving is like a chest, because it can fulfill one's wishes;
keeping precepts is like shoes, because it can lead one to be reborn in the heavens;
Meditation is like a hammer, because it subdues the mÄras.
This is what the World-Honored One has said about the proper practice of the Dharma-umbrella merit, which includes the skillful means of giving, morality, and concentration.

Here it is further explained that there are three kinds of evil conduct, namely stinginess, violation of precepts, and distraction, which give rise to various faults and are the basis for transmigrating in the evil destinies, and can destroy the merits of giving, morality, and meditation.
Therefore, the World-Honored One has shown in various ways the faults of stinginess, which are like defilements staining sentient beings and attracting undesirable consequences.
Thus, a stingy person may accumulate precious wealth but is unable to give generously, just like a hawk perching among a grove of lotus flowers.

They are unable to provide for their parents, avoid and leave when relatives gather, do not believe good words, do not enjoy the scriptures and Dharma, rely on their own wealth and cannot bear others' glory, are like intoxicated elephants whose nature is difficult to tame, are like poisonous snakes that people do not want to look at, when good people see them they all stay far away, do not enjoy rejoicing in superior meritorious deeds, when seeing those who come to guide and assist their minds become troubled, like wanting to obtain water from a dry well.
People do not want to listen to the sounds they speak, wherever they go there is no one to speak with, in the great assembly they are like fools, at the crossroads they are like a rotting corpse.

Although that foolish person dwells in the world, they are unable to stay far away from various faults and evils, are unable to protect and uphold various good merits, and are unable to nurture and grow various good seeds.
Thus, a stingy person creates the causes for poverty. Although presently wealthy, they are unable to enjoy and use it, and cannot give even a little to those who humbly seek.
You should know that such a person is like a charnel ground, which people do not enjoy relying on.
The causes and conditions of stinginess are as explained in the Sutra of the Greatly Renowned Elder.
At that time, the World-Honored One was dwelling in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Garden in the city of Sravasti.
At that time, there was a greatly renowned elder in that city who was immensely wealthy but had no son. Suddenly, he passed away.
At that time, King Prasenajit of Kosala heard of this matter and immediately went to his house, his body covered in dust.
Having arrived, he took possession of all his treasuries and all his wealth, and entrusted it all to government officials.
After the matter was finished, he returned to his carriage and went to where the World-Honored One was. He bowed his head to the Buddha's feet and sat to one side.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Why did you come here in such a hurry, your body covered in dust?
The king reported the matter in detail to the World-Honored One.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
How much wealth did that greatly renowned elder have?

His family was extremely wealthy, with abundant wealth, gold, silver, and precious treasures, and his granaries and storehouses each contained countless hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of items.

Such was his wealth and nobility that there was no one equal to him. He only used coarse and meager food and drink, and the clothes he wore were tattered and old, riding in a dilapidated cart, with a canopy made of gathered leaves.
Whenever he wanted to eat, he would first lock the door. Even though he ate during the day, he never felt full.
Even if there were Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, beggars, travelers, or performers who came seeking food and drink, not a single person ever received even a little bit.

In this way, although the elder is greatly wealthy, he does not serve his honored parents, cannot use it himself, and also does not enjoy giving to superior fields of merit. He has never heard of giving a little benefit to friends, relatives, slaves, servants, and the people. They all abandon him.

One should know that although this person is in the midst of wealth, because of his stinginess, he does not accord with them. It is like a lotus growing in filth, like a fierce tiger sitting in a wonderful garden grove, like precious delicacies placed on poisonous things, like a maá¹‡i jewel growing on a steep cliff, like a ripe sweet fruit planted on a high cliff, like a pure ground smeared with excrement, like taking poisonous medicine wishing to prolong one's life, like a prostitute claiming to be chaste, like one who is very angry wishing to be loved and respected by others, like one who misunderstands claiming to be good at debate, speaking like a foolish child without any fixed measure, speaking of what is not Dharma as Dharma, speaking of what is not good as good, attracting many kinds of worldly ridicule and slander.

They merely hoard wealth, wrongly calling it riches. Although they have precious treasures, they are of no benefit to others. They toil all day long as if they had no wealth. When people see this, they all consider it inauspicious. Even their close friends do not visit and inquire after them.
Thus, such stingy people are despised by the masses, like a flock of geese not resting in a cold forest.

Because of their wealth, they bind themselves. They do not know that life is like a mountain torrent, and do not think that the great fear of impermanence is about to arrive, and in an instant they will lose their own lives.
Know that wealth and riches also do not last long, just like the ears of an elephant, not stopping for a moment.

They cannot ask questions of Dharma teachers, and when they hear praise of generosity, their minds do not believe or delight in it. When they see someone come to guide and transform them, they hide far away. Even if they happen to see someone, they are scolded and insulted in return.

In this way, although fools have many possessions, they are no different from what is obtained in a person's dreams. They are even stingy and bury them in the ground. Even if they encounter illness and suffering, they do not seek good medicine. When they hear the doctor being called, their minds become distressed. Because of this, they sink and die.
When people hear of their death, none do not rejoice.
All parts of the body decay and are difficult to approach. Fierce flames burn them, with foul smoke and stench. Suddenly turning to ashes, they are blown away by the wind.
One should know that such a person will definitely fall into evil paths and experience various sufferings in hell.
From hell, they are reborn among hungry ghosts. Their bodies are tall and large, naked and black, and are constantly burned by raging fires. Their limbs are scorched and rotten.

Their two eyes are like pits, their bellies are extremely large, and their throats are like needles. They experience long eons without food or drink. Their skin and bones are connected but cannot support themselves.
They always eat filth to sustain their lives, smearing their lips without feeling disgust. If they see saliva, they compete to snatch it, or if they obtain a little, they experience much fear.
They are then reborn in a desolate wilderness or a dry sea, where they do not hear the word water.
Their bodies are huge, like mountain peaks, blown by fierce winds, swaying and making sounds. Flying birds come and go, pecking and grabbing them, causing them various sufferings.

Even if they become human, their appearance is extremely ugly, with black and rough skin, looking as if they have been smoked.
Their faculties are blocked, and their eyes are unclear.
They are poor and hungry, subsisting on begging, always holding bricks and stones to strike their chests.
Some obtained leftover impure food and drink, or food infested with maggots, and considered it sufficient.
They were always tormented by wind, rain, cold, heat, and bitten by mosquitoes and gadflies, forever losing happiness, fame, and auspiciousness.
Such evil retributions are extremely frightening.
This miserly karmic conduct is also described in the Sutra of the Venerable One's Questions.
At that time, the World-Honored One was staying in the Kalanda Bamboo Grove of Rajagriha.
At that time, there was an elder's son in the city who always went to where the Buddha was, delighted to hear the Dharma, and gave rise to pure faith, wishing to leave the household life.
He said to his mother:
May mother allow me to leave the household life and pursue the path in the Buddha's teachings.
His mother said:
Now you are my only child.
After my death, you can do as you wish.
The son, following her instructions, diligently sought and earned, and offered all the wealth he obtained to his mother:
Mother, please use this as you wish, and if there is any left over, use it to cultivate various meritorious deeds.
After the mother obtained the wealth, she was unwilling to give it away, hoarding it all and burying it in the ground.
When monks came to beg for food, she would raise her hand and scold them, calling them ghosts.
The son heard this and was displeased.
Why is my mother unable to give a little food and drink?
He further urged and advised her, falsely saying that he had already given it away.
Before long, the mother passed away.
At that time, the elder's son made extensive offerings to honor his mother, and then left home.

After entering the Dharma, he diligently applied himself, delighted in hearing the true Dharma, contemplated in accordance with principle, and accomplished the faculties and powers. He penetrated conditioned activities, realized the Dharma of arising and ceasing, ceased all cyclic existences, transcended the five destinies, broke through the shell of ignorance, and abandoned craving for the three realms.

He regarded gold and jewels as if they were tiles and pebbles, and did not give rise to love or hatred when smeared or cut on the body. His mind was as level as empty space, and he decisively and permanently severed all afflictions, directly realizing the fruit of arhatship.
The Great Brahma Heaven King, Indra, and the various gods all respectfully made offerings and praised him.

At that time, the Venerable One was dwelling in a grass hut on the banks of the Ganges River, practicing meditation. Suddenly a ghost appeared in front of him, naked, ugly and black like a burnt stump, hair disheveled, big belly, small neck, limbs burning, crying out in a voice.
The Venerable One asked:
Who are you?
The ghost said to the Venerable One:
I am your mother.
Twenty-five years have passed since I died and fell into the realm of hungry ghosts, suffering from extreme hunger and thirst, not hearing the names of food, drink, or water.
Even if I see a great river, it suddenly dries up;
Looking from afar at a forest of fruits, when I arrive there is nothing.
There is not even a moment of happiness.
I only wish that the Venerable One would save me and stay here to seek a little water to drink.
When the Venerable One heard this, he wept with pity and thought:
Not cultivating blessings while alive, one falls into evil paths after death.
One should give rise to utmost sincerity and repent of past faults.
The ghost said:
I was covered by the defilement of stinginess and did not give even a little to the fields of blessings.
All the various wealth and possessions I had in the past are buried in the ground in my original house.

Venerable One, quickly take those things for me, hold a great giving assembly, provide food and drink for Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, give to the poor, make offerings to the buddhas and the assembly of sages and saints,
and proclaim my name to confess my faults, wishing for me to quickly escape this suffering.
The Venerable One said:
If you can thus reproach yourself and repent, your faults will be extinguished.
The ghost said:ğŸ”½If I can thus reproach myself and repent, will my faults be extinguished?
Because in my previous life I was shameless and had no sense of wrongdoing, I have now been reborn naked and cannot stay here.
The Venerable One said to him:
If you have committed evil but do not repent, that karma is certain.
If you can confess, the sin will not increase.
Now that you have given rise to the intention, you can stay here.

At that time, the Venerable One summoned his relatives, went to his former home, dug up the buried treasures, and as he had said, held a giving assembly. He offered exquisite delicacies to the Three Jewels, and to the brahmins and beggars, satisfying them all.
At that time, the Venerable One's mother stood to one side, seeing the vast assembly of countless people, ashamed of her own ugly appearance, and wept bitterly:
I only wish that the World-Honored One would have compassion and save me.
At that time, the Venerable One prostrated with his whole body on the ground, and in a loud voice called out his mother's name, wishing to rely on this goodness to quickly liberate her.
At that time, the World-Honored One, with the power of skillful means and his majestic spiritual power, expounded the Dharma for them.
And the hundreds of thousands of sentient beings in the assembly, upon hearing the Dharma, gained understanding and attained true insight.
The ghost was freed from suffering and soon passed away.

The Venerable One then again entered concentration to observe, seeing that he had been reborn among the ghosts with wealth. He went to his place and spoke of his past causes, causing him to give rise to the aspiration and encourage him to practice giving:
Now you should cultivate merit and quickly seek liberation.
Having heard the teaching, the ghost pondered for a long time and said:
Venerable One!
I cannot give.
At that time, the Venerable One, having heard this, sighed in admiration:
You are extremely foolish, your stingy habits still remain, and you do not know that black karma will continue to entwine you.
The ghost realm is extremely evil, why are you not afraid?
Having admonished him in various skillful ways, he gradually guided and transformed him into giving two white blankets.
The Venerable One accepted them and gave them to the assembly of monks.
Before they could be sold, he ordered a monk to collect and keep them.
The ghost was still stingy and could not let go of them, so that night it secretly took them away.
When the monk lost them, he went to inform the Venerable.
The Venerable thought:
This is not done by anyone else.
I shall go and get them back.
When he arrived at the ghost's place, he indeed got back the cloth.
In this way, it stole three times, and took them back as before.
The monk in charge of the cloth also became annoyed, so he divided and distributed them to the assembly of monks.
After each received them, some used them to mend their robes.
The ghost came again and stole the robes and left.
The Buddha said:
You should know that a stingy mind is a great fault, because it binds one and causes one to fall into evil destinies for a long time.

Therefore, I now skillfully reveal this to enable sentient beings to eliminate the stains of stinginess and joyfully cultivate the vast and pure giving of Dharma. This is called the correct practice of embracing the merit-cover of giving.
